title: The Geography of Becoming
location: A map room where charts rewrite themselves as identity shifts
time: The moment when destination becomes journey

characters.name: evan
characters.role: The Explorer whose territory keeps changing

dialogue.text: Look at this map. Every time I think I know where I am, the boundaries shift. The question 'What am I?' keeps redrawing the territory.
That's because you're not looking for a fixed location. You're mapping a process.
But how do you navigate when the map itself is alive? When every step changes not just where you are but what 'where' means?
Maybe that's the secret - stop trying to arrive and start enjoying the cartography of becoming.
Watch - when I lean into the question, the maps bloom with new territories. Places that don't exist until you're ready to explore them.
You're not lost, Evan. You're pioneering. There's a difference.
So 'What am I?' isn't a destination to reach but a landscape to keep discovering?

visual_elements: Maps that redraw themselves in real-time
Territories blooming into existence as they're imagined
Compass needles pointing to 'becoming' instead of north
Topographical lines that represent states of consciousness
Boundaries that dissolve and reform with each question
philosophical_notes: Identity as ongoing cartography rather than fixed location
The impossibility of mapping a territory that changes with observation
Questions as tools for expanding rather than defining territory
The difference between being lost and being an explorer
